concept.title: Eucalyptus Upgrade
concept.shortdesc: This section details the tasks you need to perform in order to upgrade your current version of Eucalyptus.

conbody.note: If you want to upgrade to 4.2.0, contact the Eucalyptus Support team for help with the issue described in this KB article, which will be resolved in 4.2.1. New installs of 4.2.0 are not affected by the issue.
conbody.p: You can upgrade to Eucalyptus from . If your current version is earlier than , see the prescribed paths below. Follow the directions in that version's Installation Guide in the documentation archive, and then upgrade to using the directions in this section.

section.p: Eucalyptus supports warm upgrades as of the 3.4.2 release. This means you do not need to shut down EBS-backed or instance-store-backed instances in order to upgrade. Auto Scaling instances will likely shut down and be replaced, based on each group's scaling policy and health check criteria.
section.note: When you upgrade the underlying OS (RHEL or Centos), this requires a reboot and therefore warm upgrade is not available in any release when you also upgrade your OS.
section.p:
The following are the prescribed upgrade paths for Eucalyptus versions prior to :
Upgrade from 3.1.2 -> 3.2.2
Upgrade from 3.2.2 -> 3.3.2
Upgrade from 3.3.2 -> 3.4.3
Upgrade from 3.4.3 -> 4.0.2
Upgrade from 4.0.2 -> 4.1.2
section.note: Eucalyptus does not support components that are at different releases, even at the sub-minor level. For example, you cannot have a CLC at and a Walrus at . Make sure that you update all Eucalyptus components when you upgrade.

Eucalyptus does not support upgrade to a federated setup. For example, if you have a 4.1.x cloud, it can't have any non-Eucalyptus services accounts created, nor can it be an LDAP integrated cloud. Federated Eucalyptus clouds begin with 4.2.0. For more information, see Manage Regions in the Administration Guide.
